Source code is attached.
~Matt

item.title: TicTacToe
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

supamagier:

[quote]you should take all that clutter outside of your paint() and mouseClicked() methods

So it looks better + cleaner if those methods are ‘empty’.

Try making a class that loops from the start of the game to the end, and that handles all rendering to the offscreen buffer.

Do you mean I should create another (few) class(es) and divide the stuff more?

will prevent the game screen from being able to get dirty, since the loop will be repainting the canvas after its done processing events and creating the offscreen buffer.

I lost you there. What do you mean by that; can you give an example/(detailed) explanation?

Thanks for your reply.[/quote]

Methods that are called often should not be totally cluttered, but should call several lesser methods that do the actions the original method did. Also, by separating many actions into several methods, you help better-organize your code.

What I mean is, make a class that loops as long as the game is running, whose loop does the updating and calls the rendering up the render pipeline.

The render pipeline is a series of tasks that are done before the final product is rendered onto the screen. The first stage of the render pipeline, in this game, would be to process user input. The second stage is to swap the buffers (read below). And the final stage is to draw the on-screen buffer onto the game canvas.

Off-screen and On-screen buffers. An off-screen buffer is an image that stores the next frame of the game. This image is created during the render loop, and is meant to sit in storage until the next loop where it will be rendered onto the screen. The on-screen buffer is an image which has already been created and just needs to be drawn onto the screen.

The purpose of using off-screen and on-screen buffers, also called double buffering, is to enhance the overall graphics of the application. In cases where a game’s render loop is pushing a good 50-80 fps (frames per second), then the game will flicker very badly. By using double buffering, you remove most, if not all, of this flickering. And, if optional, you can also do triple buffering.

Why use a render loop? This is just good game design. A render loop does all the processing, rendering of the buffers, swapping of the buffers, and call to the paint method (to render the on-screen buffer onto the canvas). In cases where you don’t use a render loop, the following things can happen:

-Without double buffering, flickering can occur
-Without a loop calling the repainting of a canvas, no animations are possible
-Without a loop calling the repainting of a canvas, a frame going on top of the game frame or applet can distort the rendered image, aka, make it ‘dirty’

Well, there’s my 3-cents, hope you can improve the game!

Read full topic

item.title: TicTacToe
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

Yes, I know how switch statements work (the basics, anyways) But I don’t know what if/else statements in my code can become a switch statement. I’ll read the tut.

Read full topic

item.title: TicTacToe
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[code]int toSwitch = 10;
// Your standard if-else statement.
if(toSwitch == 10) {
// Something if toSwitch was 10.
// But since it is 10, ofcourse it will end here.
} else if(toSwitch == 100) {
// Something if toSwitch was 100.
} else {
// Something if it is neither 10 or 100.

// This would be the above code, except in a switch statement.
switch(toSwitch) {
case 10:
// The same as if(toSwitch == 10)
break;
case 100:
// The same as if(toSwitch == 100).
break;
default:
// The same as the else statement. If it is neither 10 or 100.
break;
}[/code]
Also, I suggest reading the tutorial on switch statements here: http://72.5.124.55/docs/books/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/switch.html

Read full topic

item.title: TicTacToe

item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

you should take all that clutter outside of your paint() and mouseClicked() methods
So it looks better + cleaner if those methods are 'empty'.
Try making a class that loops from the start of the game to the end, and that handles all rendering to the offscreen buffer.
Do you mean I should create another (few) class(es) and divide the stuff more?
will prevent the game screen from being able to get dirty, since the loop will be repainting the canvas after its done processing events and creating the offscreen buffer.
I lost you there. What do you mean by that; can you give an example/(detailed) explanation?

Thanks for your reply.

Read full topic

item.title: TicTacToe
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

You should expand it and make it more Object-Oriented. Plus, you should take all that clutter outside of your paint() and mouseClicked() methods.

Try making a class that loops from the start of the game to the end, and that handles all rendering to the offscreen buffer. Plus, it processes the mouseClicked events. This will save up on the clutter in the main class and will prevent the game screen from being able to get dirty, since the loop will be repainting the canvas after its done processing events and creating the offscreen buffer.

Read full topic
